questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: No specific achievements to report this year.  It has been one of consolidation of projects and looking to new opportunities.   GraphTIVA work is occurring through a separate project.

questions.question: collaborations_industry_linkages
answers: As a key laboratory in the Digital Research and Innovation Capability Platform, the Advanced Visualisation Laboratory is actively pursuing industry partnerships in Health, Smart Satellites, Mining, and other fields.  With the exception of potential industry applications of GraphtiVA,m OzSTAR is not actively part of the strategy for current industry discussions.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
This project has primarily been used as a development platform for the gravitational-wave parameter estimation software, Bilby*.

A paper detailing the software has been published in Astrophysical Journal Supplements: Ashton, Hübner, Lasky, Talbot, et al, (2019) “Bilby: A user-friendly Bayesian inference library for gravitational-wave astronomy” ApJS 241, 27.  The software has been selected by the LIGO/Virgo Scientific Collaborations as the code that will perform all astrophysical inference of gravitational-wave events.  At the time of writing, we are in the middle of an extensive LIGO/Virgo internal code review process; at the conclusion of this (hopefully in the coming month), all new gravitational-wave events will be analysed using Bilby.

This software, and the OzStar project, have been used in a number of subsequent papers:
* Hernandez Vivanco, Smith, Thrane, & Lasky (2019) “Accelerated detection of the binary neutron star gravitational-wave background” arXiv:1903.05778 (under review)
* Talbot, Smith, Thrane, & Poole (2019) “Parallelized inference for gravitational-wave astronomy” arXiv:1904.02863 (under review)
* Payne, Talbot, & Thrane (2019) “Higher order gravitational-wave modes with likelihood reweighting” arXiv:1905.05477 (under review)
* Powell & Müller (2019) “Gravitational wave emission from 3D explosion models of core-collapse supernovae with low and normal explosion energies” MNRAS 487, 1178
* Ashton, Lasky, Graber & Palfreyman (2019) “Rotational evolution of the Vela pulsar during the 2016 glitch” Nature Astronomy (accepted; arXiv:1907.01124)
* Easter, Lasky, Casey, Rezzolla, & Takami (2019) “Computing fast and reliable gravitational waveforms of binary neutron star merger remnants” arXiv:1811.11183 (under review)
* Sarin, Lasky, & Ashton (2019) “X-ray afterglows of short gamma-ray bursts: magnetar or fireball” ApJ 872, 114
* Sarin, Lasky, Sammut, & Ashton (2018) “X-ray guided gravitational-wave search for binary neutron star merger remnants” PRD 98, 043011

Important results in gravitational-wave astronomy from the above list includes significant speed-ups of gravitational-wave inference using GPUs and also new algorithms for detecting the stochastic gravitational-wave background.  Outside of direct gravitational-wave parameter estimation, the Bilby code is also being used to study and understand multiple astrophysical phenomena, including short gamma-ray bursts, fast radio bursts, and pulsar glitches.  In the last of those categories, we recently had a paper accepted to Nature Astronomy, that provides the best limit on a glitch rise time and identifies two new features of glitches that had not previously been identified.  

Bilby was highlighted as one of three primary science cases for the $2.8M NCRIS-funded Gravitational-Wave Data Centre.  It has further been used as the primary basis of a ~$1.2M LIEF bid that is currently under review, led by Monash CIs Thrane and Lasky, along with Swinburne (Hurley & Bailes).  Finally, the Bilby project has been awarded two ADACS Software Support Grants worth a total of ~19 FTE weeks.  

* The original code name way Peyote, which explains the project name.

questions.question: collaborations_collaborations
answers:
National Collaborations throughout OzGrav have been enabled by this project.  For example, planning for an Australian dedicated high-frequency gravitational-wave observatory is well underway, with the astrophysical modelling of what could be achieved with such an instrument being led by Bilby projects and performed on the OzStar cluster.

Internationally, the Bilby software is in the process of being adopted by the LIGO and Virgo Scientific Collaborations as the code that will perform all parameter estimation of future gravitational-wave events.  These two collaborations have more than 1,000 members globally; the parameter-estimation working group alone has more than 150 members, all of whom will be using the Bilby code that was developed as part of this project.

answers: None.  The support provided has been excellent, and there have been few issues along the way.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: "Inferring the population properties of binary neutron stars with gravitational-wave measurements of spin" by Zhu et al. published in Physical Review D, 2018, 98, 043002. This paper proposes a new framework that enables constraints to be set on neutron star magnetic field evolution and equation of state using gravitational wave observations of neutron star mergers.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: Most of the work that has been done on OzSTAR has focussed on testing new algorithms for structure-finding in cosmological simulations, using the VELOCIraptor code. This work supports the Genesis Simulations thread of the ARC CoE ASTRO 3D and the EAGLE Simulations programme, and some of it has been published in Elahi et al. 2019 (eprint arXiv:1902.01010, accepted for publication in PASA). We have also used OzSTAR to run some large volume cosmological simulations that are being used in the forthcoming set of papers, to be submitted for publication later this year.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
We have used a self-consistent, semi-numerical model of galaxy evolution and reionization (RSAGE, Seiler et al. 2019) to study the Epoch of Reionization. We have investigated (1) how the ionization topology, i.e. the evolution of the sizes and distribution of the ionized regions, changes as the properties of the underlying high-redshift galaxies are varied and (2) how 21cm signal observations with the forthcoming Square Kilometre Array (SKA) could distinguish between different scenarios. In particular, we considered three different reionization scenarios that differ in their trends of the ionizing escape fraction (escape fraction of ionizing photons from galaxies into the intergalactic medium (IGM)) and cover the physically plausible range, i.e. the escape fraction effectively decreasing, being constant, or increasing with halo mass.

Firstly, we have found that plotting the large-scale versus the small-scale 21cm power provides a strong indicator for the halo or stellar mass dependency of the escape fraction. Our calculations predict that 800h observations with SKA1-LOW will be sufficient to constrain the global trend of the escape fraction with halo mass (Seiler et al. 2019, https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.tmp.1578S/abstract).

Secondly, computing the bispectra of the 21cm signal for our three different reionization scenarios, we have found the 21cm bispectra to be sensitive to the resulting ionization topologies that significantly differ in their size distribution of ionized and neutral regions throughout reionization. From squeezed to stretched triangles, the 21cm bispectra features a change of sign from negative to positive values. The position of the change of sign provides a tracer of the size distribution of the ionized and neutral regions, and allows us to identify three major regimes that the 21cm bispectrum undergoes during reionization. In particular the regime during the early stages of reionization, where the 21cm bispectrum tracks the peak of the size distribution of the ionized regions, provides exciting prospects for pinning down reionization with the forthcoming Square Kilometre Array (Hutter et al. 2019 (submitted), https://arxiv.org/abs/1907.04342).

questions.question: highlights-image_caption
answers: Evolutionary regimes of the 21cm bispectrum during the Epoch of Reionization. The lower panel shows how the three major regimes can be determined by the peaks of the size distribution of the ionized (R_ion) and neutral (R_neutral) regions. In these regimes, the bispectrum is (1) sensitive to the peak of the size distribution of the ionized regions (red), (2) sensitive to the shapes of the neutral and ionized regions (black), and (3) sensitive to the abundance and shapes of the neutral regions (blue). The upper panel sketches the typical shape of the bispectra in these regimes, illustrating the typical triangle configurations at which the bispectra changes their sign. The square panels depict the real space patterns that the bispectra with different triangle configurations are probing.

answers.publication: The Escape Fraction of Ionizing Photons During the Epoch of Reionization: Observability with the Square Kilometre Array; Jacob Seiler, Anne Hutter, Manodeep Sinha, Darren Croton; MNRAS  487 (2019) 5739-5752

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: We performed a model selection study of intrinsic pulsar spin noise using the first data release of the International Pulsar Timing Array. We find tentative evidence of a time scale at which red pulsar spin noise starts becoming white. In addition to that, we have discovered sources of systematic errors in model selection and investigated implications of spin noise at times to detection of the nHz stochastic gravitational-wave background. A paper with our findings is in preparation.

questions.question: highlights-image_caption
answers: Log Bayes Factors in favour of a broken power-law hypothesis against a power-law hypothesis for red noise simulations (vertical axis) are plotted against red noise simulation amplitudes (horizontal axis). Both plots demonstrate that we can not confidently resolve a spectral turnover at 10 nHz (bottom plot) or its absence (top plot) in individual pulsar red noise within 10 years of observations due to sample variance. Nevertheless, the correct model can be recovered with high confidence using multiple simulations.

questions.question: difficulties_problems
answers: Not problems, really, more like lessons learned. 1) When I applied I thought I would be able to make use of the large number of cores in the KNL nodes. I only later found out that it is common knowledge that these nodes perform very poorly and result in overall longer wall-clock times than the normal nodes with fewer cores. Should this have been caught at the proposal time? 2) I struggled to use my allocated time despite running pretty much full time on the 32 cores of the regular nodes. I overestimated the time in part because I had thought I would be running on twice as many cores.

answers.publication: Parameter estimation and identifiability in a neural population model for electro-cortical activity, Agus Hartoyo, Peter Cadusch, David Liley, Damien Hicks, PLoS Computational Biology, 2019
answers.bibtex: @article{10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006694,     author = {Hartoyo, Agus AND Cadusch, Peter J. AND Liley, David T. J. AND Hicks, Damien G.},     journal = {PLOS Computational Biology},     publisher = {Public Library of Science},     title = {Parameter estimation and identifiability in a neural population model for electro-cortical activity},     year = {2019},     month = {05},     volume = {15},     url = {https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006694},     pages = {1-27},     abstract = {Author summary Electroencephalography (EEG), where electrodes are used to measure electric potential on the outside of the scalp, provides a simple, non-invasive way to study brain activity. Physiological interpretation of features in EEG signals has often involved use of collective models of neural populations. These neural population models have dozens of input parameters to describe the properties of inhibitory and excitatory neurons. Being able to estimate these parameters by direct fits to EEG data holds the promise of providing a real-time non-invasive method of inferring neuronal properties in different individuals. However, it has long been impossible to fit these nonlinear, multi-parameter models effectively. Here we describe fits of a 22-parameter neural population model to EEG spectra from 82 different subjects, all exhibiting alpha-oscillations. We show how only one parameter, that describing inhibitory dynamics, is constrained by the data, although all parameters are correlated. These results indicate that inhibitory synaptic activity plays a central role in the generation and modulation of the alpha-rhythm in humans.},     number = {5},     doi = {10.1371/journal.pcbi.1006694} }

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
Indications from Gaia data release 2 are that the tip of the red giant branch (a population II standard candle related to the helium flash in low mass stars) is close to -4 in absolute I magnitude in the Cousins photometric system. Our sample was high-latitude southern stars from the thick disk and inner halo, and our result was consistent with longstanding findings from globular clusters, whose distances were calibrated with RR Lyrae stars. As the Gaia mission proceeds, there is every reason to think an accurate Galactic geometric calibration of tip of the red giant branch will be a significant outcome for the extragalactic distance scale.

Durre & Mould explored the gas morphology and excitation mechanisms of the ionization cones of the type II Seyfert galaxy NGC 5728. Kinematics derived from near-infrared and optical data from the SINFONI and MUSE Integral Field Units on the VLT reveal active galactic nucleus (AGN)-driven outflows powered by a supermassive black hole of mass 3.4 × 10^7 M ☉, bolometric luminosity of 1.46 × 10^44 erg s^-1, Eddington ratio of 3.3 × 10^-2, and an accretion rate of 2.7 × 10^-2 M ☉ yr^-1. The symmetric bicone outflows show rapid acceleration to ±250 km s^-1 at ̃250 pc, decelerating to ̃130 km s^-1 at 500 pc from the AGN, with an estimated mass outflow rate of 38 M ☉ yr^-1 the mass ratio of outflows to accretion is 1415. The kinetic power is ̃1.5 × 10^42 erg s^-1, 1% of the bolometric luminosity. Over the AGN active lifetime of ̃10^7 yr, 1.6 × 10^8 M ☉ of gas can become gravitationally unbound from the galaxy, a large proportion of the gas mass available for star formation in the nuclear region. The outflow axis is nearly parallel to the plane of the galaxy. This geometry supports the unified model of AGNs, as these angles preclude seeing the accretion disk, which is obscured by the dusty torus.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
We have used resources on the Swinburne OzSTAR supercomputer for our project: "Determining the kinematic structure of jets in post-asymptotic giant branch binary stars". During the past two periods (ASTAC 2018-B and 2019-A) we have been rewarded a total of 294.4kSUs (102.4kSUs + 192kSUs). For the first part of this project, we have written a model-fitting code with a Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) routine, in order to determine the spatio-kinematic structure of these jets. This is done by creating synthetic spectra of the system from a geometrical model, which is then fitted to our obtained high-resolution optical spectra using the MCMC-routine. 
Thanks to the allocated time on the Swinburne OzSTAR supercomputer, we have successfully tested this generic code. We also successfully determined the structure of IRAS19135+3937, a post-AGB binary system with a jet. From these results, we can further investigate the accretion and jet launching physics of this system.

We have finished this first part of the project and have submitted a paper to the Astronomy & Astrophysics Journal (Bollen et al. 2019, submitted).

For our current project (part II), we are using this application to study the jet-diversity in our whole sample of jetting post-AGB binaries. This jet-diversity will offer us further possibilities to understand jet properties. By studying the diverse jet properties of the rich sample of post-AGB binaries as a function of orbital parameters, we can provide further insight into the origin of the accreted gas: circumbinary disk or post-AGB star.

questions.question: highlights-image_caption
answers: Dynamic spectra created from the observed spectra ( left ) and the model spectra ( right ). The model dynamic spectra where created using the best-fitting model with the stellar jet configuration. The encircled region in the model spectra highlights the extra red-shifted absorption feature that is created by the model, but which we do not observe.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: Solar flares are hugely energetic phenomena occurring regularly in the solar atmosphere.  Flares begin with a reconnection event in solar corona, generating accelerated charged particles interacting with the surrounding plasma medium.  This causes a downward propagation of energy through various mechanisms such as accelerated particles, magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) waves, radiation and thermal conduction.  When a flare is sufficiently strong, this energy can travel through the chromosphere and impact with the photosphere.  This causes acoustic pulses to travel through the internal layers of the Sun, known as a sunquake.  By simulating sunquakes we look to improve our knowledge on the type of impacts likely to cause the quakes and gain information relating to the subsurface structure of strongly magnetic regions (local helioseismology) where quakes occur.  OzStar has allowed 3D MHD simulations producing a catalogue of various impacts and resulting sunquakes.  A paper is in preparation which quantifies the effect of varying both the impacting source and the surrounding magnetic field.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
- We have completed a joint analysis of galaxy redshift and peculiar velocity datasets from the 6-degree Field Galaxy Survey (led by Caitlin Adams as part of her PhD completed this year).  Our analysis self-consistently measures the growth rate of cosmic structure using information from both the amplitude of galaxy velocities and redshift-space distortions in the galaxy clustering pattern, showing that these determinations are consistent and strengthening the measurement of the local growth rate.

- We have studied the statistics of the baryon acoustic peak in the galaxy clustering pattern in a range of recent galaxy surveys (led by postdoc Rossana Ruggeri).  We have focussed in particular on the accuracy of the error estimation, and how this is affected by sample variance and should be best determined.

- We have led combined cosmological analyses of weak gravitational lensing and galaxy clustering as members of the Kilo-Degree imaging Survey (KiDS) and Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI) collaborations (led by faculty Chris Blake).  Our work involved statistical measurements related to lensing and clustering, the creation of realistic galaxy mock catalogues, and the study of techniques to infer the source redshift distributions of the lensing surveys.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: This project co-ordinates activities of the large-scale structure working group of the Taipan Galaxy Survey, due to commence later in 2019.  The main achievement in the previous year is that we have completed a series of 600 realistic Taipan mock catalogues (work led by Cullan Howlett and Pascal Elahi at University of Western Australia), including both the galaxy redshift and peculiar velocity components of the Taipan survey, using approximate N-body simulation techniques (comoving Lagrangian acceleration) coupled with a halo occupation distribution matched to properties of low-redshift galaxies.  These mocks have formed the basis of a series of cosmological analyses preparing for the Taipan survey, including measurement of baryon acoustic oscillations, redshift-space distortions, density-field reconstruction, void catalogues and joint density/velocity analyses.  (This last analysis formed the final chapter of Caitlin Adam's PhD thesis.)

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: b"I have successfully mirrored the rice artificial microRNA designer based on Max Planck's Web microRNA Designer 3 (WMD3). The original WMD3 is very busy, accepting thousands of requests from international researchers daily. Consequently, it will take weeks to months before one can receive the results. Using the local version, the identification and design of microRNAs can be done in just a few hours. Four minor research students were able to utilise the biocomputing pipeline in designing artificial microRNAs to silence the expression of key candidate genes in rice. Four more students will access the said biocomputing pipeline this coming sem. Some of these students will continue to pursue PhD research on functional genomic validation of key genes involved in rice grain quality and nutrition. "

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
Octahedral and decahedral anatase particles were modified with nanoparticles of noble metals (Au, Ag, Cu). For the first time, noble-metal-modified particles have been comparatively analyzed to recognize how the different types of faceted anatase morphology can influence photocatalytic activity of samples modified by noble metals in different reaction systems. Selective deposition of gold/silver nanoparticles should result in significant improvement of photocatalytic activity under visible irradiation, and thus high overall activity under solar radiation enabling its commercial applications.

Thermo-optical properties of the nanodisc and metal hole array plasmonic perfect absorber metasurfaces were designed and characterized at mid-infrared wavelengths. Both, radiation emitter and detector systems operating in various spectral domains are highly sought after for a diverse range of applications, one example being future sensor networks employed in the internet-of-things. The highest efficiency of radiation-to-heat and heat-to-radiation conversion was obtained for Au-Si-Au composite structures.

answers: Concept of Kirchhoff’s metasurface devices fabricated by mass production photo-lithography on 8-inch Si wafers. Inset illustrates optical-to-thermal and thermal-to-optical energy conversion by the Kirchhoff’s metasurfaces.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
This year we completed one of the main studies of galaxy transformation based on the SAMI Galaxy Survey (Cortese et al. 2019). This work shows, for the first time, that satellites do not undergo any major structural transformation during their quenching phase. The combination of GAMA, SAMI data as well as predictions from the EAGLE simulation showcases the important role played by progenitor bias in our understanding of galaxy evolution and suggest that an accurate quantification of star formation histories of galaxies at different redshift is the most promising route to properly link progenitors to their progeny.
 
 
Variations in stellar V/σ and SFR for satellite galaxies with respect to star-forming centrals. Points are colour coded by stellar mass. Dashed lines and cyan bands show the average and standard deviation for centrals. The thick black and thin green lines show the running median and 20–80 per cent percentile ranges for (V/σ) in bins of (SFR).

questions.question: highlights-image_caption
answers: Left: Variations in stellar V/σ and SFR for satellite galaxies with respect to star-forming centrals. Points are colour coded by stellar mass. Dashed lines and cyan bands show the average and standard deviation for centrals. The thick black and thin green lines show the running median and 20–80 per cent percentile ranges for (V/σ) in bins of (SFR). Right: A  cartoon  summarising  the  evolutionary  scenario emerging  from  this  work  and  the  potential  effect  ofprogenitor bias.  The  top  panel  shows  the  increase  of V/σ with  decreasing lookback time/redshift for galaxies while being star-forming cen-trals (solid green line), and the change in V/σ once they become satellites  (red  line).  The  green  dashed  line  shows  the  expected evolution of V/σ in case the galaxy would have remained a star-forming central until z∼0. The true ∆(V/σ) and the value obtained via our matching technique are shown by the black vertical arrows. The bottom panel shows the case of SFR, with the changes  for  centrals  and  satellites  highlighted  by  the  blue  and pink  lines,  respectively.  In  this  case,  the  observed  ∆(SFR)  atz∼0 is always smaller than the real value.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
-  First fast transient (minute-timescale) paper submitted using the Deeper, Wider, Faster (DWF) program data on OzSTAR.
-  ADACS project for the DWF database and user interface well underway.  
-  Successful DWF operational run on June 24 - 29 with 32 telescopes worldwide and in space at all wavelengths, including particle detectors, to detect and study fast transients (millisecond-to hours duration).  DWF coordinated 17 telescopes from radio through gamma-ray and cosmic ray/neutrino for simultaneous, fast-cadneced observations of the same fields at the same time.  Real-time data processing performed on all data, including CTIO Dark Energy Camera optical data processing on OzSTAR, throughout the night.  This fast data processing, and fast identification and analysis of 175,000 transient candidates, enabled very fast response, and later-time, follow up observations by an additional 15 telescopes worldwide.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: Using OzSTAR, we repeatedly performed several large Monte Carlo simulations to verify an algorithm that is used to estimate Faraday rotation along the line of sight to astronomical sources such as pulsars, magnetars, and Fast Radio Bursts.  The simulation included generating millions of pulsed signals over a large range of rotation measures and signal-to-noise ratios, and testing that in each case the algorithm produced both the expected value and an accurate estimate of uncertainty.  Our tests exposed a fundamental error in the mathematical derivation of the algorithm, which we corrected before publication.  The results of this test provided much greater confidence in the Faraday rotation measures derived from our experimental data and reported in Caleb et al. (2019; https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2019MNRAS.487.1191C/abstract).

questions.question: highlights-image_url
answers: b"It's not very flash, but Figure 4 of https://academic.oup.com/mnras/article-abstract/487/1/1191/5490400 presents the results of the simulation after correcting the Faraday rotation estimation algorithm"

questions.question: highlights-image_caption
answers: Verification of the Faraday Rotation Measure Refinement algorithm via Monte Carlo simulation on OzStar.  Top panel: Ratio between the mean estimated uncertainty and the standard deviation of Rotation Measure estimates as a function of signal-to-noise ratio. The expected ratio of unity is indicated by the dashed line. Bottom panel: The standard deviation of the Rotation Measure estimates as a function of signal-to-noise ratio (S/N). The standard deviation is expected to scale inversely with S/N as indicated by the line with a slope of −1.

    author = {Caleb, M and van Straten, W and Keane, E F and Jameson, A and Bailes, M and Barr, E D and Flynn, C and Ilie, C D and Petroff, E and Rogers, A and Stappers, B W and Venkatraman Krishnan, V and Weltevrede, P},

    month = {05},
    abstract = "{We study the polarization properties of 22 known rotating radio transients (RRATs) with the 64-m Parkes radio telescope and present the Faraday rotation measures (RMs) for the 17 with linearly polarized flux exceeding the off-pulse noise by 3σ. Each RM was estimated using a brute-force search over trial RMs that spanned the maximum measurable range \\$\\pm 1.18 \\times 10^5 \\, \\mathrm\\{rad \\, m^2\\}\\$ (in steps of 1 \\$\\mathrm\\{rad \\, m^2\\}\\$), followed by an iterative refinement algorithm. The measured RRAT RMs are in the range |RM| 1–950 rad m−2 with an average linear polarization fraction of 40 per cent. Individual single pulses are observed to be up to 100 per cent linearly polarized. The RMs of the RRATs and the corresponding inferred average magnetic fields (parallel to the line of sight and weighted by the free electron density) are observed to be consistent with the Galactic plane pulsar population. Faraday rotation analyses are typically performed on accumulated pulsar data, for which hundreds to thousands of pulses have been integrated, rather than on individual pulses. Therefore, we verified the iterative refinement algorithm by performing Monte Carlo simulations of artificial single pulses over a wide range of S/N and RM. At and above an S/N of 17 in linearly polarized flux, the iterative refinement recovers the simulated RM value 100 per cent of the time with a typical mean uncertainty of 5 rad m−2. The method described and validated here has also been successfully used to determine reliable RMs of several fast radio bursts (FRBs) discovered at Parkes.}",

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
We calculate spectral functions of Bose polaron in the presence of a synthetic spin-orbit coupling (SOC), and discover some interesting properties that does not show up in conventional BEC. This result was posted to arXiv (1902.08333) early this year and is now under review in Physical Review Letters. Using OzSTAR allows us to carry calculations in a large parameter space and generate data for illustrative figures. In the near future, we plan to calculate excitations of Bose-Einstein condensation in the presence of a variety of SOC and external traps.

We also collaborate with Dr. Ye Cao, who was a previous post-doc here in Swinburne. We are currently calculating the superconducting properties of Penrose crystals, the energy spectrum of which have self-similarity and cannot be resolved analytically. Therefore, we carry numerical simulations on OzStar. By solving the superconducting critical temperature of singlet and triplet state respectively, we give the boundary of two symmetries, and further classify each symmetry and get four topological states p+ip, d+id, f+if and g+ig. The latter two hardly appear in common materials.

In another collaboration with Dr. Jing Zhou, a previous visitor of our group, we study the Higgs mode and its dissipation in a Fermi superfluid system. We also calculate polaron properties in the BCS-BEC crossover.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: Through the research activities of Dr Giorgos Vernardos (University of Gronigen), the GERLUMPH resource continues to play an important international role in the field of quasar microlensing.  Dr Vernardos has extended the online e-Tools to include a Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST) simulator, in collaboration with Prof Timo Anguita at the University of Andres Bello in Chile.   GERLUMPH data was used to establish and demonstrate that deep learning could be used to enhance quasar light curve analysis, with applications to LSST.  GERLUMPH data is also being used to make predictions of microlensing flax ratios - important for placing constraints on quasar accretion disk properties - for the Euclid space telescope.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: New intermolecular potentials were developed from first principles.  These ab intio potential provide greatly improved insights into the interactions of atoms, enabling genuine predictions in the absence of any prior experimental data.  Progress was also made in further understanding the flow behaviour of water in carbon nanotubes (CNT). In particular, the role of various water models was unambiguously determined for the first time.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers:
* (near) Completion of the TAO 5 project. TAO 5 makes TAO deployable on other HPC infrastructure. OzStar has been used to modularise TAO and as a testing ground for deployment. This work was then extended to NCI.
* Transition of TAO data, from being hosted in a relational database to a KD tree format. This change has allowed us to optimise how TAO data is processed, and to efficiently allow for the hosting of larger datasets. This latter point is in anticipation of the next generation of ASTRO 3D Genesis simulations, and new Uchuu Simulation currently being run in Japan and for which we are partners.
* New national datasets that have been made available through TAO for the astronomy community: Tiamat/Meraxes.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: b"Two final papers of Matt Agnew's thesis completed in the past 12 months, both of which relate to numerical searches for habitable exoplanets.  We search the entire population of currently known multiple planet systems that contain at least one Jovian planet and find 28 candidates which could host dynamically stable habitable exo-Earths, of which 16 would be detectable with the ESPRESSO spectrograph on the VLT.  A second paper present an alternative approach to rapidly assess the dynamical stability of multiple planet systems discovered with TESS, and determine whether an exoplanet system would be capable of hosting a dynamically stable Earth-mass companion in its habitable zone.   We show that it is possible to scale and translate the stability signature in (a,e) space, and combine several together for multiple planetary systems, in order to conservatively assess the dynamical stability of newly discovered multiple planet systems without the need for exhaustive numerical simulations. "

2. "ESPRESSO Science Verification Proposal - A high-precision fine-structure constant from a new absorber". Participants: John K. Proposal accepted and observations scheduled 26/27 Aug 2019. These observations are a world first and if all goes well should produce remarkable results: all 4 VLTs are being fibre-optically coupled, forming the largest optical telescope in the world, feeding into a single spectrograph.

questions.question: highlights-achievements
answers: This is a relatively new project. Over the past 6 months we have mainly focussed on porting, testing and benchmarking our new MWA pulsar processing pipeline on OzSTAR. The project involves processing large volumes of MWA voltage-capture data to produce sensitive tied-array beams (~1000s across the full field of view) which will then be processed to search for any pulsar candidates. The new beam-forming software runs twice faster on OzSTAR (compared to the Galaxy cluster at Pawsey HPC) and almost 10 times faster compared to our standard (single-pixel) beam-forming software.

questions.question: collaborations_collaborations
answers: Australian collaborators include Swinburne and CASS. The overseas collaborators: Auckland University of Technology (New Zealand), ASTRON (The Netherlands), Shanghai Astronomical Observatory (China), and the University of Milwaukee (USA).

questions.question: difficulties_problems
answers: This is relatively new project that required substantial in-house (Curtin) development of MWA-specific software for data processing. Aside from some delay (a few months) encountered in the related development, and some glitches in data transport at early stages (from Pawsey to OzSTAR) no major problems were encountered. Thanks to Swinburne HPC support, the most recent bottleneck with I/O has now been resolved and the workflow (of the related search jobs) has been suitably altered to ensure they exploit the SSDs. We are currently testing the new processing pipeline and will soon commence ramping up on the processing.
